Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Performance and Evolution of Environmentally Responsive Biomaterials in a Unique Biological Adhesive System: Spider Orb Web Capture Threads
Award.AbstractNarration: Materials change their properties in response to the environment in ways that are often detrimental to performance. However, a new generation of "smart materials" capitalizes on environmental responsiveness to improve performance in the laboratory. This project investigates how such "smart materials" evolve and function in nature, focusing on how adhesives adapt to fluctuating humidity in the environment. Spider capture threads are sophisticated composite structures that generate adhesion through multiple mechanisms that could respond synergistically or independently to the environment. Adhesion starts with the surface contact of sticky glycoproteins that are encased in liquid glue droplets and is then enhanced when those droplets and the underlying axial thread to which they are attached stretch and resist thread "pull-off" by forming a broad, suspension bridge-like interface. This whole process is controlled in part by cocktails of salts in the glue droplets that absorb atmospheric water, which then lubricates the glue and controls the extension of the droplets and axial threads. This project combines biology and materials science to compare the molecular compositions of glues, the adhesiveness of capture threads, and how webs capture insects across a community of spiders to understand how biological "smart" materials respond to their environments. It will inspire the development of new synthetic adhesive systems and "smart", environmentally responsive materials. The project will provide in depth training in interdisciplinary research to PhD, undergraduate and high school students. It will also develop new educational resources for K5-K12 summer camps and teacher workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

Orb weaving spiders are important members of terrestrial ecosystems where their webs use sticky capture threads to retain insect prey. This natural adhesive consists of tiny, regularly spaced glue droplets, each composed of a glycoprotein sphere enclosed in a solution whose molecules attract atmospheric moisture, maintaining glycoprotein adhesion and pliability. Droplet extensibility allows a thread to sum the adhesive forces of multiple droplets.

These droplets' volumes change during the day as they track environmental humidity. The droplets of species found in low vegetation, where humidity drops during the day, are more hygroscopic than those found in humid environments, such as forest edges and interiors. Thus, optimal viscosity of glycoprotein from species that live in low humidity habitats is achieved at lower humidity than that of species found in humid habitats. Thread adhesion is greatest when glycoprotein viscosity is low enough to allow a droplet to spread and establish adhesive contact, but high enough to ensure that the glycoprotein remains cohesive as it extends and transfers this adhesive force to the capture thread's support line.

Humidity-influenced droplet performance translates into a web's ability to retain insects, as documented by experiments that measured the active struggle time required by house flies to escape from capture thread arrays. A model showed that glycoprotein viscosity made the greatest contribution to prey retention time, followed by glycoprotein area of adhesive contact and glycoprotein extension. This documents the mechanism by which natural selection tunes the composition of a droplet's glycoprotein and hygroscopic molecules to a species' habitat.

Orb web glue droplets are capable of adhering, stretch, and pull free over 40 times with minimal loss of performance, allowing a thread to reattach to an insect as it struggles to escape. The performance of droplets of species from exposed habitats is unchanged or improved when exposed to the harsh effects of ultraviolet radiation B. Droplets also perform well under hot, summer afternoon temperatures, which slightly reduce glycoprotein viscosity to mitigate the drying effects of these conditions.

These studies and others that are being prepared for publication document the remarkable and dynamic properties of orb spider capture threads. Documenting that glue droplets are both environmentally responsive and able to cycle through many extensions shows for the first time that they are smart biological materials. These foundational findings will guide material scientists and chemists seeking the inspiration of nature to develop effective, versatile, and environmentally friendly adhesives for a range of applications.

Broader Impacts

Most people are familiar with orb weaving spiders and many of those who do not like spiders respond with interest to these spiders' webs. Our outreach activities have capitalized on this interest to engage a broad audience in the biology and role of spiders in the ecosystem and the processes that scientists use to learn about the natural world.  This audience has ranged from grade school children, to educators, to the general public.

We offer a summer field experience for grade school children in a forest setting, which teaches them about spider biology, with a focus on orb weaving spiders.  This includes a contest where students dust orb webs with cornstarch and measure critical web features to see who can find the biggest web, and webs with the most widely spaced capture threads.  This is followed by an exercise to test the ability of different species' webs to retain simulated prey. Students leave with a booklet that provides a spider quiz, pictures to color and label, a word search puzzle, and a list of resources on spider biology.

A workshop for middle and high school science teachers introduces them to the biology of orb weaving spiders, shows them how they can use orb webs and their threads to engage students in science and mathematics, gives them experience in capturing and characterize spider webs, and provides them with resources to use in their classrooms.

Each fall we contribute an entry on Orb Weaving Spiders at Virginia Tech's Hokie Bugfest, a broad-reaching event that celebrates all aspects of arthropod biology and draws over 8,000 visitors. Our table incorporates a poster that explains how orb webs are constructed and describes the composition and humidity response of their capture threads. This is supported by a movie and a magnified view of capture threads in a large web displayed on collecting frame. Pictures of 12 common orb weaving species spark conversations and we encourage those who stop to pick up and examine living examples of spiders displayed in glass vials.

Other outreach also included a presentation on "Getting to Know Virginia's Spiders" for a local Master Naturalist chapter. Additionally, articles about our research on orb weaving spiders capture threads appeared on the front page of the Roanoke Times and in Virginia Tech's Fralin Explorer magazine, and an interview with Brent Opell aired on WVTF's NPR radio station.
